pullRequest.title: New Rust module structure.
pullRequest.bodyText:
This commit changes the structure of the generated Rust project in order
to improve ergonomics and speed up compilation.
We used to place all function and type declarations in a single module
in types/lib.rs.  This was suboptimal for several reasons.  First,
we had to rely on name mangling for namespace isolation, e.g., None
would get compiled to std_Some::std_None (and even that was not
guaranteed to avoid conflicts altogether).  This made writing extern
functions and types, as well as using the Rust API cumbersome.  Second,
since all declarations were placed in the same module, it was very easy
to run into name clashes with manually written Rust code.  Third,
since the entire module is re-generated and re-compiled every time, no
incremental compilation was possible.
We change this structure by generating a Rust module hierarchy that
precisely matches the DDlog hierarchy, with one Rust module for each
DDlog module containing all type and functiond declarations, as well as
all extern Rust code for the module.
This addresses the first two problems above and makes a step towards
solving the third problem.  Compilation is not yet incremental; however
it is not in principle possible to make the DDlog compiler incremental
by only re-compiling affected modules.  In order to also compile Rust
code incrementally, we would have to further break up the generated code
into multiple crates, which will be much easier with the current
structure.
One side effect of this refactoring is that I had to rename the std
library to ddlog_std to avoid name clashes with the Rust std library
that gets automatically imported by all programs.  I tried different
techniques to avoid the clashes, but there does not seem to exist a
robust way.

This commit makes another change that helps speed up compilation.  This
should have been done in a separate commit, but the two ended up being
too tangled to separate them.
We used to implement Serialize and Deserialize traits for the
DDValue type using serde_typetag crate that uses some black magic to
auto-generate serialization/deserialization code for trait objects.
Turns out this magic is extremely expensive in terms of compilation time
and generated code size.  It literally slows down compilation by a
factor or two for some of our programs.  I don't have an explanation and
filed an issue against typetag: dtolnay/typetag#25.
As a workaround, we now generate serialization/deserialization code
in the DDlog compiler, and it's much more lightweight.  Note that
DDValue serialization/deserialization is only used by the
distributed-ddlog crate.  More specifically, it needs to
serialize/deserialize Update<DDValue> objects.  Since these objects
contain relation id for each value, we can implement a custom
deserializer that first reads relations id and picks the value type to
deserialize based on that.  See details in
src/lib.rs/UpdateSerializer.

commit.message:
Module.hs: Drop support for #[macro_use].

This is in preparation for the new code generation model where each
DDlog module maps into a separate Rust module.

We used to support extern libraries that import macros from other Rust
crates using `#[macro_use]`.  This introduced some extra complexity, as
macro_use imports had to be copied to the main module of a crate. The
complexity was going to get worse as we move to the new compilation
model.

`#[macro_use] is now outdated in Rust, and so we simplify the compiler
slightly by dropping support for it.

beforeCommit.message:
CLI option to enable 32-bit nested timestamp.

This option is useful in recursive programs where the recursive fragment of the
program may require more than `2^16` iterations.  Since in practice most
recursive computations perform fewer iterations, DDlog uses a 16-bit iteration
counter (or timestamp in the Differential Dataflow terminology) by default.
When this is not sufficient, the `nested-ts-32` can be used to tell DDlog to use
32-bit iteration counter instead.

Consider the following example that enumerates all numbers from `0` to `65599`
and stores the last 70 numbers in an output relation:

```
relation Rb(x: u32)
output relation Rque(x: u32)

Rb(0).
Rb(x+1) :- Rb(x), x < 65599.
Rque(x) :- Rb(x), x > 65530.
```

The recursive fragment of this program performs `65600` iterations; hence a
16-bit counter is not sufficient.

If the DDlog project was compiled without the `nested-ts-32` flag, 32-bit
timestamps can be enabled when compiling the generated Rust project by enabling
its using the `nested_ts_32` feature:

```
cargo build --release --features "nested_ts_32"
```
